Results: Roger Federer won his 6th title, beating Marin Čilić. Caroline Wozniacki her first Grand Slam defeating Simona Halep in the final.
There were 6 skiing events, 7 snowboarding events, 2 snowmobiling events and 2 snow bike events, with the host nation USA winning 24 medals, and Canada second with 8 medals.
The Philadelphia Eagles won their first Super Bowl, defeating the defending champions New England Patriots, 41–33.
Norway and Germany tied with 14 gold medals each, though Norway had more total medals.
The leading nation was the Netherlands (12 medals), followed by Germany, Great Britain and Australia (all on 6 medals)
The USA topped the medal table for the 2nd time with 36 total medals (13 gold). Host nation South Korea finished 16th including taking its first gold.
US player Patrick Reed won his first major title, one stroke ahead Rickie Fowler.
Over 4,400 athletes from 71 Commonwealth Games Associations took part in the event, with Australia clearly leading the medal table with 80 gold medals (198 total), followed by England and India.
The race was won by 10/1 shot Tiger Roll in a photo finish
The race was won by the favorite Justify.
Sweden won their second consecutive and eleventh overall title after defeating Switzerland in the final
Chelsea beat Manchester United 1-0. Chelsea lost to Arsenal in 2017.
Real Madrid beat Liverpool in the final 3–1, for their third consecutive and 13th overall title.
Over 400 athletes from 14 countries participated. Colombia led the medal table, followed by Brazil.
The race was won by Daniel Ricciardo (Red Bull) followed by Sebastian Vettel (Ferrari) and Lewis Hamilton (Mercedes).
The men's singles was won by defending champion Rafael Nadal, his 11th French Open title. Simona Halep won her first Grand Slam title in Women's Singles.

Location: Washington DC and Las Vegas, USA
Results: The Washington Capitals defeated Vegas Golden Knights 4-1 to win their first championship in their 44th season.
Defending champion Golden State Warriors swept the Cleveland Cavaliers 4-0. It was the first time the same two teams met for the championship four years in a row.
France beat Croatia 4-2 in the final, their 2nd World Cup title
The general classification race was won by Welshman Geraint Thomas of Team Sky, his first win. His teammate and four-time Tour champion Chris Froome finished 3rd.

Location: Circuit de la Sarthe, Le Mans, France
Results: Won by the No. 8 Toyota Gazoo Racing driven by Fernando Alonso, Kazuki Nakajima, and Sébastien Buemi, from pole position.

Location: Shinnecock Hills Golf Club, New York
Results: Defending champion Brooks Koepka won his 2nd straight U.S. Open, one stroke ahead of Tommy Fleetwood.
Novak Djokovic won the Gentleman's Singles title and Angelique Kerber won the Ladies Singles title.

Location: Carnoustie Golf Links,	Carnoustie,	Angus,	Scotland
Results: Francesco Molinari won his first major championship and became the first Italian player to win a major.
The USA and Australia dominated the medal table, winning most of the gold medals.
In a knock-out only format, New Zealand won both the men's and women's event, defeating England in the men's final and France in the women's final.
Defending champions the Netherlands won for a record 8th time, defeating Ireland 6–0 in the final.
It was the first edition of the European Championships. Russia was awarded the European Championships Trophy for achieving the most gold medals across all seven sports.
37 nations took part, with Mexico leading the medal table, from Cuba and host nation Colombia.
Athletes representing 91 countries participated in 36 sports.

Location: Bellerive Country Club, Town and Country, Missouri
Results: Brooks Koepka won his third career major title, shooting a PGA Championship record of 264 and finishing two strokes ahead of Tiger Woods.
China led the medal tally for the tenth consecutive time
Novak Djokovic won the men's singles title, defeating del Potro in the final. In women's singles, Naomi Osaka defeated Serena Williams, becoming Japan's first ever Grand Slam singles champion.
This was the first world rowing championships where the competition schedule was gender-equal. The medals were evenly spread, with 4 countries winning 3 golds each.
Poland defended their world title, defeating the reigning olympic champions Brazil in straight sets
68 nations took part
The road race was won by Spain's Alejandro Valverde (men's) and The Netherlands' Anna van der Breggen (women's)
Europe regained the Ryder Cup, winning by 17½ points to 10½.
West Coast Eagles beat Collingwood by 5 points, the Eagles 4th fourth premiership.
Minor premiers Sydney Roosters defeated the defending premiers Melbourne Storm 21–6 to claim their 14th premiership title.
Serbia won their first world title, defeating Italy in five sets at the final
This 4th Invictus Games included 11 medal sports. About 500 athletes from 18 countries participated. Although medals are awarded, no medal tally is recorded.
The Boston Red Sox beat the LA Dodgers 4-1 to win their ninth title in franchise history.

In the men's all-round, Defending champion Xiao Ruoteng of China lost the title on a tiebreaker to Russia's Artur Dalaloyan. In the women's all -round, US gymnast Simone Biles won an unprecedented 4th title.
China led the medal tally. After the IWF nullified all world records, this Championship saw a total of 72 senior world records set.
Won by Cross Counter, ridden by Kerrin McEvoy and trained by Charlie Appleby.

In the light flyweight category, Indian Mary Kom beat Ukrainian Hana Okhota to win gold, becoming the first woman boxer to win six gold medals in the AIBA World Boxing Championships. China won 4 gold medals, followed by Taiwan with 2.
Belgium won the tournament for the first time after defeating the Netherlands 3–2 in the final on a penalty shoot-out after a 0–0 draw.
The USA led the medal tally with 36 medals, beating Russia then China.
